idAbs.para: Permanently deletes data from disk. All types of geographic data supported by ArcGIS, as well as toolboxes and workspaces (folders, geodatabases), can be deleted. If the specified item is a workspace, all contained items are also deleted.

summary.para: Permanently deletes data from disk. All types of geographic data supported by ArcGIS, as well as toolboxes and workspaces (folders, geodatabases), can be deleted. If the specified item is a workspace, all contained items are also deleted.

pythonReference.para: The input data to be deleted.

dialogReference.para: The input data to be deleted.

pythonReference.para: Data type of the Input Data Element. Data type is displayed for informative purposes and cannot be changed.

dialogReference.para: Data type of the Input Data Element. Data type is displayed for informative purposes and cannot be changed.

bullet_item.para: Data currently in use in another ArcGIS application cannot be deletedâ€”the tool will fail with ERROR 000464.
Deleting a shapefile also deletes ancillary files such as the metadata, projection, and index files.
Deleting a folder moves the folder to the system Recycle Bin, where it can be restored or permanently deleted.

Deleting a geometric network demotes all the feature classes in the network to simple feature types; Edge feature classes become line feature classes; and junction feature classes become point feature classes. Deleting the network also deletes all the related network tables and the orphan junction feature class from the geodatabase.
Deleting a database connection file does not delete the ArcSDE database. A database connection file is simply a shortcut to the database.
Deleting a relationship class deletes the row corresponding to that relationship from the relationship table.

scriptExample.title: Delete Example (Python Window)
scriptExample.para: The following Python Window script demonstrates how to use the Delete function in immediate mode.
scriptExample.code:
import arcpy from arcpy import env
env.workspace = "C:/data" arcpy.Copy_management(("majorrds.shp"), "majorrdsCopy.shp") arcpy.Delete_management("majorrdsCopy.shp")

scriptExample.title: Delete Example 2 (Stand-alone Python Script)
scriptExample.para: The following Python script demonstrates how to use the Delete function in a stand-alone script.
scriptExample.code:
# Name: Delete_Example2.py # Description: Delete majorrdsCopy.shp # Author: ESRI
# Import system modules import arcpy from arcpy import env
# Set workspace ENV.workspace = "C:/data"
# Set local variables in_data0 = "majorrds.shp" out_data = "majorrdscopy.shp" data_type = ""
# Execute Copy arcpy.Copy_management(in_data, out_data, data_type)
# Execute Delete arcpy.Delete_management(out_data, data_type)
